author: sharkhuh
content:
I find it very weird so much engineering effort is being put into the to idea someone can suddenly double the hashrate and hit TTD too quickly. If someone had that capability, Ethereum would already be unsecured.

Seems like a no brainer the easier solution is the one where the correct TTD is baked into the release to reduce human error and ensure a much smoother merge.

And in the event this magical entity can double the hashrate, you can see it coming and coordinate to push the TTD out with an override as an emergency move

author: gwintery
content: Systematically, IMO, all attack vectors should be scored via a risk assessment method to determine the best course of action. We should be in a situation whereby the weighted overall risk of an attack is met with an appropriate level of response. Of course, quantifying these will be notoriously difficult for some attack vectors, but it can be done. Someone doubling hashrate on one of the biggest and most decentralized crypto seems to score quite low in the feasibility of attack, but it is quite criticalif it were to happen.

author: sky.cactus
content: There is essentially no engineering effort being put into this.  It is entirely a discussion.  All paths are approximately equal in terms of engineering, and allare incredibly similar to each other.

author: undying1200
content: I agree that while there is no engineering effort being put into it, I do I think we are getting bogged down (a distraction) on testnet hashrate manipulation that is not possible on mainnet. I would expect the tom foolery to only increase from miners as we get closer to the merge where profitability is so low that moving to a testnet for a few days does not matter. The solution is quite simple, if possible; change the testnet client TTD to a more smoothing calculation so it is relatively unaffected by large changes in hashrate. While this might be cheating, we know this part of the current TTD is solid and can be shipped with the mainnet release. This way we can move forward instead of spending too much time trying to figure out how to stop miners from slowing down the merge rollout until they figure out another way.
